elements.content: Three nickel 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (1,4-CDC) coordination polymers, Ni6(OH)6(1,4-CDC)3(H2O)6·2H2O (1), Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4·4H2O (2), and Ni(1,4-CDC)(H2O)4 (3), have been synthesized from an identical starting mixture as temperature-dependent products. Their characteristic structures and magnetic and sorption behaviors are reported.
elements.clean_text: Three nickel 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (1,4-CDC) coordination polymers, Ni6(OH)6(1,4-CDC)3(H2O)6⋅2H2O (1), Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4⋅4H2O (2), and Ni(1,4-CDC)(H2O)4 (3), have been synthesized from an identical starting mixture as temperature-dependent products. Their characteristic structures and magnetic and sorption behaviors are reported.

elements.content: Polynuclear core-based nickel 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate coordination polymers have been synthesized from an identical starting mixture at different temperatures. Ni6(OH)6(CDC)3(H2O)6·2H2O (1) forms a 2D layer based on novel hexanuclear nickel prismane cluster building units, while Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4·4H2O (2) forms a 3D open framework with a 1D channel of 17.1 × 3.5 Å2.
elements.clean_text: Polynuclear core-based nickel 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate coordination polymers have been synthesized from an identical starting mixture at different temperatures. Ni6(OH)6(CDC)3(H2O)6⋅2H2O (1) forms a 2D layer based on novel hexanuclear nickel prismane cluster building units, while Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4⋅4H2O (2) forms a 3D open framework with a 1D channel of 17.1 × 3.5 Å2.

elements.content: Design and synthesis of coordination polymers are of great current interest for their intriguing topologies and their potential properties as functional materials. This class of complexes contains two central components (building units), inorganic parts (single polyhedra, clusters, or chains), and organic ligands. The versatility of organic ligands and the diversity of inorganic units have led to a wide array of functions of coordination polymers. The employment of polynuclear cores (clusters or chains) as inorganic building units for the preparation of porous coordination polymers is of particular interest. Because the metal ions are locked into their positions by carboxylate groups, the polynuclear cores are sufficiently rigid to produce extended frameworks with high structural stability. Furthermore, introduction of polynuclear cores into the coordination polymers can achieve multifunctional materials, for example, combining magnetism with porosity. It is well-known that hydrothermal or solvothermal reactions are widely used in the preparation of coordination polymers, and some unexpected and interesting polynuclear core-based coordination polymers have been obtained in these processes. However, the control of products in hydrothermal reactions is still an exciting challenge to chemists, since many reaction variables can affect the final products. In particular, among the reaction variables, temperature plays a key role. Here we report three nickel compexes obtained from an identical starting mixture through hydrothermal reactions where only the reaction temperature was changed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and synthesis of coordination polymers are of great current interest for their intriguing topologies and their potential properties as functional materials. This class of complexes contains two central components (building units), inorganic parts (single polyhedra, clusters, or chains), and organic ligands. The versatility of organic ligands and the diversity of inorganic units have led to a wide array of functions of coordination polymers. The employment of polynuclear cores (clusters or chains) as inorganic building units for the preparation of porous coordination polymers is of particular interest. Because the metal ions are locked into their positions by carboxylate groups, the polynuclear cores are sufficiently rigid to produce extended frameworks with high structural stability. Furthermore, introduction of polynuclear cores into the coordination polymers can achieve multifunctional materials, for example, combining magnetism with porosity. It is well-known that hydrothermal or solvothermal reactions are widely used in the preparation of coordination polymers, and some unexpected and interesting polynuclear core-based coordination polymers have been obtained in these processes. However, the control of products in hydrothermal reactions is still an exciting challenge to chemists, since many reaction variables can affect the final products. In particular, among the reaction variables, temperature plays a key role. Here we report three nickel compexes obtained from an identical starting mixture through hydrothermal reactions where only the reaction temperature was changed.

elements.content: During the search for coordination polymers with novel topologies, we focused our attention on the hydrothermal reactions of 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2CDC) with nickel at different temperatures. The interest of nickel lies in facile construction of its unusual clusters and chains with polyhedra linked by edges, vertices, or faces. Combining the flexibility of 1,4-H2CDC with abundant nickel polyhedra may result in coordination polymers with unusual topology.
elements.clean_text: During the search for coordination polymers with novel topologies, we focused our attention on the hydrothermal reactions of 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2CDC) with nickel at different temperatures. The interest of nickel lies in facile construction of its unusual clusters and chains with polyhedra linked by edges, vertices, or faces. Combining the flexibility of 1,4-H2CDC with abundant nickel polyhedra may result in coordination polymers with unusual topology.

elements.content:
Synthesis. All chemicals were obtained from Aldrich and TCI and used without further purification.

Ni 6 (OH) 6 (1,4-CDC) 3 (H 2 O) 6 ·2H 2 O, 1. The mixture of 1,4-H2CDC (1.0 mmol, 0.1720 g), Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (1.0 mmol, 0.2490 g), cyclohexanol (5 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave and then heated at 170 °C for 3 days. The product, green hexagonal platelets, was separated by filtration. Yield:  35%. Elemental analysis (%) for 1 (C24H52O26Ni6):  calcd:  C:  26.00, H:  4.73; Found:  C:  25.79, H:  5.01. IR (KBr):  ν (cm-1) 3387 (br w), 2949 (m), 1560 (s), 1419 (s), 1295 (w), 1217 (w), 930 (w), 830 (m), 649 (w), 592 (w), 485 (w).

elements.content: Ni 3 ( OH) 2 (1,4 - CDC) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·4H 2 O, 2. The compound 2 was obtained by a procedure similar to that for compound 1 only changing the reaction temperature from 170 to 140 °C. elements.content: Crystallography. The X-ray diffraction measurements for compounds 1−3 were carried out on a Rigaku Mercury CCD at 298 K, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR 97. All compounds were expanded using Fourier techniques. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water molecules were generated geometrically. All calculations were carried out on a SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for all compounds are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text: Crystallography. The X-ray diffraction measurements for compounds 1-3 were carried out on a Rigaku Mercury CCD at 298 K, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR 97. All compounds were expanded using Fourier techniques. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2. The hydrogen atoms except for those of water molecules were generated geometrically. All calculations were carried out on a SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for all compounds are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

Magnetic Measurements. Direct current (dc) magnetic measurements were made on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 2−300 K and with applied fields 1 T. Measurements were performed on single-crystal samples.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic Measurements. Direct current (dc) magnetic measurements were made on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 2-300 K and with applied fields 1 T. Measurements were performed on single-crystal samples.

elements.content: Three nickel complexes, Ni6(OH)6(1,4-CDC)3(H2O)6·2H2O (1), Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4·4H2O (2), and Ni(1,4-CDC)(H2O)4 (3), were synthesized from 1,4-H2CDC and Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O through hydrothermal reactions at 170, 140, and 120 °C, respectively (Scheme ). Compounds 1 and 2 are polynuclear nickel core-based coordination polymers. Interestingly, the amount of hydroxide ions incorporated into the structure increases with increasing reaction temperature. The OH-/Ni2+ ratio of 1 to 3 is 1, 2/3, 0, respectively. This trend shows increasing condensation at higher reaction temperatures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Three nickel complexes, Ni6(OH)6(1,4-CDC)3(H2O)6⋅2H2O (1), Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4⋅4H2O (2), and Ni(1,4-CDC)(H2O)4 (3), were synthesized from 1,4-H2CDC and Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O through hydrothermal reactions at 170, 140, and 120 °C, respectively (Scheme ). Compounds 1 and 2 are polynuclear nickel core-based coordination polymers. Interestingly, the amount of hydroxide ions incorporated into the  structure increases with increasing reaction temperature. The OH-/Ni2+ ratio of 1 to 3 is 1, 2/3, 0, respectively. This trend shows increasing condensation at higher reaction temperatures.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="cg050363gh00001" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic xlink:href="cg-2005-00363g_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

In this work, we adopted a biphasic approach in which 1,4-H2CDC was dissolved in cyclohexanol that is not miscible with water, and water was used to dissolve nickel acetate. This approach led to three kinds of single crystals at different reaction temperatures. Three complexes can all be reproduced well. If we use standard hydrothermal conditions in which 1,4-H2CDC and nickel acetate were dissolved in water, we were unable to obtain single crystals for structural characterization, and only unknown phases shown from X-ray powder diffraction patterns were obtained.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we adopted a biphasic approach in which 1,4-H2CDC was dissolved in cyclohexanol that is not miscible with water, and water was used to dissolve nickel acetate. This approach led to three kinds of single crystals at different reaction temperatures. Three complexes can all be reproduced well. If we use standard hydrothermal conditions in which 1,4-H2CDC and nickel acetate were dissolved in water, we were unable to obtain single crystals for structural characterization, and only unknown phases shown from X-ray powder diffraction patterns were obtained.

elements.content: Ni 6 (OH) 6 (1,4-CDC) 3 (H 2 O) 6 ·2H 2 O (1). Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 adopts a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure with a hexanuclear prismatic nickel cluster Ni6(OH)6(-CO2)3(H2O)6 as an inorganic building unit. The coordination environments of nickel atoms are shown in Figure (top). The six Ni(II) atoms are crystallographically equivalent, and each of them is coordinated to three μ3-OH groups, one water molecule, and two oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups, which gives rise to a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment around each metal center (bond length of Ni−O is in the range of 2.045(3)−2.108(4) Å, the angle of O−Ni−O is in the range of 83.55(14)−97.44(18)°, and O−Ni−Owater is in the range of 173.13(14)−177.56(15)°) The prismatic core is constructed by two six-membered rings of Ni3(OH)3 with alternating corners at top and bottom faces, whose centers are located on the 6-fold rotatory inversion axis. The sides of the prismane are comprised of six four-membered (−Ni−OH)2 rings, each of which is spanned by the carboxylate groups that form a hexanuclear prismatic Ni6(OH)6(−CO2)3(H2O)6 cluster (Figure , top right). Each prismane cluster is connected to six adjacent prismane clusters through six −C6H10− groups of CDC ligands, forming a 2D layer structure. To the best of our knowledge, this kind of hexanuclear nickel prismane cluster has never been seen in the polymetallic nickel(II) complex family, although [Sn6O6] and [Cu6X6] (X = Br, I) prismane structures are common motifs in biochemistry.
elements.clean_text: Ni  6  (OH)  6  (1,4-CDC)  3  (H  2  O)  6 ⋅2H  2  O (1). Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 adopts a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure with a hexanuclear prismatic nickel cluster Ni6(OH)6(-CO2)3(H2O)6 as an inorganic building unit. The coordination environments of nickel atoms are shown in Figure  (top). The six Ni(II) atoms are crystallographically equivalent, and each of them is coordinated to three μ3-OH groups, one water molecule, and two oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups, which gives rise to a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment around each metal center (bond length of Ni-O is in the range of 2.045(3)-2.108(4) Å, the angle of O-Ni-O is in the range of 83.55(14)-97.44(18)°, and O-Ni-Owater is in the range of 173.13(14)-177.56(15)°) The prismatic core is constructed by two six-membered rings of Ni3(OH)3 with alternating corners at top and bottom faces, whose centers are located on the 6-fold rotatory inversion axis. The sides of the prismane are comprised of six four-membered (-Ni-OH)2 rings, each of which is spanned by the carboxylate groups that form a hexanuclear prismatic Ni6(OH)6(-CO2)3(H2O)6 cluster (Figure , top right). Each prismane cluster is connected to six adjacent prismane clusters through six -C6H10- groups of CDC ligands, forming a 2D layer structure. To the best of our knowledge, this kind of hexanuclear nickel prismane cluster has never been seen in the polymetallic nickel(II) complex family, although [Sn6O6] and [Cu6X6] (X = Br, I) prismane structures are common motifs in biochemistry.

elements.content: (Top, left) view of coordination environments of nickel atoms (green) in1, (top, right) hexanuclear prismatic cluster unit; (bottom) perspective view down the c axis showing 2D layer structure.
elements.clean_text: 1  (Top, left) view of coordination environments of nickel atoms (green) in1, (top, right) hexanuclear prismatic cluster unit; (bottom) perspective view down the c axis showing 2D layer structure.

elements.content: Ni 3 (OH) 2 (1,4 - CDC) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·4H 2 O (2). The structure of 2 is similar to Ni3(OH)2(O2C-C2H2-CO2)(H2O)4·4H2O. There are two nickel atoms:  Ni(1) and Ni(2), one CDC, four water molecules, and a hydroxide ion in the asymmetric unit (Figure , top). Ni(1) is coordinated to two hydroxide groups (O(3), O(3b)) and four oxygen atoms (O(2b), O(2c), O(2d), O(2e)) from four carboxylate groups, Ni(2) is coordinated to two hydroxide groups (O(3), O(3a)), two water molecules (O(4w), O4(wa)), and two oxygen atoms (O(1), O(1b)) from two carboxylate groups. The trimer, which consists of two edge-sharing symmetry-related nickel octahedra (Ni(2)−Ni(2a)) and links via μ3-OH to a vertex of the Ni(1) octahedron, acts as the repeating structural motif to form a one-dimensional (1D) nickel-oxide chain (Figure , middle). These chains lie parallel to the c-axis and are connected by −C6H10− groups of CDC ligands to form a 3D open framework (Figure , bottom). Large dumbbell-shaped channels down the c-axis consist of four CDC walls and four nickel oxide chains. The size of the channel determined by considering van der Waals radii is 17.1 × 3.5 Å2. The guest and coordinated water molecules are occupied in the channels. Calculation of the free space in 2 reveals that about 28.8% of the structure is occupied by water molecules. A fumarate analogue of compound 2 reported by Chaudhri has 2D pores. The pore's size is 13.5 × 1.5 Å2 and 3.0 × 5.5 Å2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Ni  3  (OH)  2  (1,4 - CDC)  2  (H  2  O)  4 ⋅4H  2  O (2). The structure of 2 is similar to Ni3(OH)2(O2C-C2H2-CO2)(H2O)4⋅4H2O. There are two nickel atoms: Ni(1) and Ni(2), one CDC, four water molecules, and a hydroxide ion in the asymmetric unit (Figure , top). Ni(1) is coordinated to two hydroxide groups (O(3),  O(3b)) and four oxygen atoms (O(2b), O(2c), O(2d), O(2e)) from four carboxylate groups, Ni(2) is coordinated to two hydroxide groups (O(3), O(3a)), two water molecules (O(4w), O4(wa)), and two oxygen atoms (O(1), O(1b)) from two carboxylate groups. The trimer, which consists of two edge-sharing symmetry-related nickel octahedra (Ni(2)-Ni(2a)) and links via μ3-OH to a vertex of the Ni(1) octahedron, acts as the repeating structural motif to form a one-dimensional (1D) nickel-oxide chain (Figure , middle). These chains lie parallel to the c-axis and are connected by -C6H10- groups of CDC ligands to form a 3D open framework (Figure , bottom). Large dumbbell-shaped channels down the c-axis consist of four CDC walls and four nickel oxide chains. The size of the channel determined by considering van der Waals radii is 17.1 × 3.5 Å2. The guest and coordinated water molecules are occupied in the channels. Calculation of the free space in 2 reveals that about 28.8% of the structure is occupied by water molecules. A fumarate analogue of compound 2 reported by Chaudhri has 2D pores. The pore's size is 13.5 × 1.5 Å2 and 3.0 × 5.5 Å2, respectively.

elements.content: Ni(1,4-CDC)( H 2 O) 4 (3). Compound 3 consists of isolated nickel atoms that are octahedrally coordinated to four water molecules and two oxygen atoms from the two CDC bridges, resulting in a 1D coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text: Ni(1,4-CDC)( H  2  O)  4   (3). Compound 3 consists of isolated nickel atoms that are octahedrally coordinated to four water molecules and two oxygen atoms from the two CDC bridges, resulting in a 1D coordination polymer.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties. The magnetic behaviors of compounds 1−3 are shown in the form of χM T versus T and χM versus T plots (Figure ). For compound 1, the value of χM T at room temperature (5.97 cm3 K mol-1) is lower than an expected value for six noninteracting NiII ions (S = 1) with g = 2.1 (6.62 cm3 K mol-1). On cooling of the sample, the χM T decreases slowly. This behavior suggests the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between NiII ions through μ3-OH and syn− syn carboxylate bridges. Here, a ferromagnetic contribution is also expected through a μ3-OH bridge with Ni−O(1)−Ni angles of 91.62 and 92.18° (see Table ). However, the spins of NiII ions are completely canceled in the Ni6 (even number) cluster core. The 1/χM vs T plot in the temperature range of 300−25 K obeys the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ of −126 K, which is consistent with the magnetic behavior. The increase of χM value under 20 K is due to paramagnetic impurities. For 2, the χM T value at room temperature (3.55 cm3 mol-1 K) corresponds to three magnetically isolated NiII ions. χM T gradually increases from 3.84 to 4.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 40 K with lowering temperature. Under 40 K, χM T decreases more steeply down to 3.70 cm3 K mol-1 at 10 K and then again increases to 4.20 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The first increase of χM T can be attributed to a ferromagnetic interaction between Ni(2) centers through two μ3-OH bridges with Ni(2)−O(3)−Ni(2a) angle of 95.78° (see Table ). The decrease of χM T below 40 K results from an antiferromagnetic interaction between Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers through one μ3-OH bridge with a Ni(1)−O(3)−Ni(2) angle of 120.12°. The triangle Ni3 (odd number) core consists of one Ni(1) and two Ni(2) centers should have two remnant magnetic spins within the core due to the combination of the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic contributions. The abrupt increase of χM T under 10 K means a tendency of an ordering of remnant spins (ferrimagnetism) within the 1D chain. Ac susceptibility results show no long-range magnetic ordering until 2 K. A Curie−Weiss plot (300−40 K) gives a Weiss constant θ of 1.58 K. For 3, χM T gradually decreases from 1.14 to 1.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 30 K and then decreases more steeply down to 0.25 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which indicates contributions of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between spin centers and zero-field splitting of NiII ions. χM can be fit to the Curie−Weiss expression, χM = C/(T − θ), with C = 1.15 cm-3 mol K (g = 2.14), θ = −4.88 K.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic Properties. The magnetic behaviors of compounds 1-3 are shown in the form of χM T versus T and χM versus T plots (Figure ). For compound 1, the value of χM T at room temperature (5.97 cm3 K mol-1) is lower than an expected value for six noninteracting NiII ions (S = 1) with g = 2.1 (6.62 cm3 K mol-1). On cooling of the sample, the χM T decreases slowly. This behavior suggests the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between NiII ions through μ3-OH and syn- syn carboxylate bridges. Here, a ferromagnetic contribution is also expected through a μ3-OH bridge with Ni-O(1)-Ni angles of 91.62 and 92.18° (see Table ). However, the spins of NiII ions are completely canceled in the Ni6 (even number) cluster core. The 1/χM vs T plot in the temperature range of 300-25 K obeys the Curie-Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ of -126 K, which is consistent with the magnetic behavior. The increase of χM value under 20 K is due to paramagnetic impurities. For 2, the χM T value at room temperature (3.55 cm3 mol-1 K) corresponds to three magnetically isolated NiII ions. χM T gradually increases from 3.84 to 4.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 40 K with lowering temperature. Under 40 K, χM T decreases more steeply down to 3.70 cm3 K mol-1 at 10 K and then again increases to 4.20 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The first increase of χM T can be attributed to a ferromagnetic interaction between Ni(2) centers through two μ3-OH bridges with Ni(2)-O(3)-Ni(2a) angle of 95.78° (see Table ). The decrease of χM T below 40 K results  from an antiferromagnetic interaction between Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers through one μ3-OH bridge with a Ni(1)-O(3)-Ni(2) angle of 120.12°. The triangle Ni3 (odd number) core consists of one Ni(1) and two Ni(2) centers should have two remnant magnetic spins within the core due to the combination of the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic contributions. The abrupt increase of χM T under 10 K means a tendency of an ordering of remnant spins (ferrimagnetism) within the 1D chain. Ac susceptibility results show no long-range magnetic ordering until 2 K. A Curie-Weiss plot (300-40 K) gives a Weiss constant θ of 1.58 K. For 3, χM T gradually decreases from 1.14 to 1.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 30 K and then decreases more steeply down to 0.25 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which indicates contributions of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between spin centers and zero-field splitting of NiII ions. χM can be fit to the Curie-Weiss expression, χM = C/(T - θ), with C = 1.15 cm-3 mol K (g = 2.14), θ = -4.88 K.

elements.content: Temperature dependences of the χM T and χM for 1 (top), 2 (middle), and 3 (bottom) under an applied field of 1 T. Insets are χ-1 vs T plots of 1−3.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependences of the χM T and χM for 1 (top), 2 (middle), and 3 (bottom) under an applied field of 1 T. Insets are χ-1 vs T plots of 1-3.

elements.content: Thermal Behavior of 2. The guest water molecules occupying the channels can be removed at an elevated temperature without collapsing the host framework as confirmed by TGA and X-ray diffraction studies (Figure ). The TG curve of 2 shows three main events between room temperature and 500 °C. The first (25−70 °C) is assigned to the removal of four equivalents of guest water molecules in the channels (obsd 9.1%, calcd 10.0%). The second event (120−150 °C) corresponds to the loss of four coordinated water molecules (obsd 11.0%, calcd 10.1%). The last weight loss of 52.9% (calcd 50.9%) between 290 and 440 °C corresponds to the elimination of the organic component.
elements.clean_text: Thermal Behavior of 2. The guest water molecules occupying the channels can be removed at an elevated temperature without collapsing the host framework as confirmed by TGA and X-ray diffraction studies (Figure ). The TG curve of 2 shows three main events between room temperature and 500 °C. The first (25-70 °C) is assigned to the removal of four equivalents of guest water molecules in the channels (obsd 9.1%, calcd 10.0%). The second event (120-150 °C) corresponds to the loss of four coordinated water molecules (obsd 11.0%, calcd 10.1%). The last weight loss of 52.9% (calcd 50.9%) between 290 and 440 °C corresponds to the elimination of the organic component.

elements.content: X-ray thermodiffractogram of2 in air (30−180 °C).
elements.clean_text: 4  X-ray thermodiffractogram of2 in air (30-180 °C).

elements.content: Adsorption of 2. To confirm the permanent porosity of 2, samples of dehydrated 2 were subjected to gas adsorption measurements using CO2, Ar, and N2, whose kinetic diameters are known to be 3.3, 3.4, and 3.64 Å, respectively (Figure ). The adsorption measurements show that dehydrated 2 adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar and N2, which is associated with the kinetic diameters of the guest molecules versus the pore size. The sorption of CO2 revealed a type I behavior typical for microporous materials. The Langmuir surface area of 2 is calculated to be 146 m2 g-1. This type of framework could provide a subtle size of porous aperture which is useful for recognizing small size gas molecules.
elements.clean_text: Adsorption of 2. To confirm the permanent porosity of 2, samples of dehydrated 2 were subjected to gas adsorption measurements using CO2, Ar, and N2, whose kinetic diameters are known to be 3.3, 3.4, and 3.64 Å, respectively (Figure ). The adsorption measurements show that dehydrated 2 adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar and N2, which is associated with the kinetic diameters of the guest molecules versus the pore size. The sorption of CO2 revealed a type I behavior typical for microporous materials. The Langmuir surface area of 2 is calculated to be 146 m2 g-1. This type of framework could provide a subtle size of porous aperture which is useful for recognizing small size gas molecules.

elements.content: Isotherms for the adsorption of N2 and Ar at 77 K, and CO2 at 195 K on dehydrated 2.
elements.clean_text: 5  Isotherms for the adsorption of N2 and Ar at 77 K, and CO2 at 195 K on dehydrated 2.

elements.content: The adsorption isotherms for MeOH and EtOH were also measured (Figure ). The amount of adsorption was calculated by using the Langmuir analysis and which for every formula unit, 0.5 of MeOH, 0.3 of EtOH molecules can be adsorbed.
elements.clean_text: The adsorption isotherms for MeOH and EtOH were also measured (Figure ). The amount of adsorption was calculated by using the Langmuir analysis and which for every formula unit, 0.5 of MeOH, 0.3 of EtOH molecules can be adsorbed.

elements.content: Isotherms for the adsorption of MeOH and EtOH at 298 K on dehydrated2.

elements.content: In conclusion, three new nickel cyclohexanedicarboxylates have been synthesized hydrothermally from the same combination of reagents at different temperatures. Compound 1 forms a 2D layer based on the first reported Ni6(OH)6(-CO2)3(H2O)6 prismane cluster. Compound 2 forms a 3D open framework with 1D large dumbbell-shaped channels along the c axis, while 3 is a 1D coordination polymer. The results of the magnetic measurements reveal that 1 is an antiferromagnet, while 2 displays a tendency of ferrimagnetic ordering. Dehydrated 2 adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar and N2, which could be useful for providing functional pores.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, three new nickel cyclohexanedicarboxylates have been synthesized hydrothermally from the same combination of reagents at different temperatures. Compound 1 forms a 2D layer based on the first reported Ni6(OH)6(-CO2)3(H2O)6 prismane cluster. Compound 2 forms a 3D open framework with 1D large dumbbell-shaped channels along the c axis, while 3 is a 1D coordination polymer. The results of the magnetic measurements reveal that 1 is an antiferromagnet, while 2 displays a tendency of ferrimagnetic ordering. Dehydrated 2 adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar and N2, which could be useful for providing functional pores.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis. All chemicals were obtained from Aldrich and TCI and used without further purification.

Ni 6 (OH) 6 (1,4-CDC) 3 (H 2 O) 6 ·2H 2 O, 1. The mixture of 1,4-H2CDC (1.0 mmol, 0.1720 g), Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (1.0 mmol, 0.2490 g), cyclohexanol (5 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave and then heated at 170 °C for 3 days. The product, green hexagonal platelets, was separated by filtration. Yield:  35%. Elemental analysis (%) for 1 (C24H52O26Ni6):  calcd:  C:  26.00, H:  4.73; Found:  C:  25.79, H:  5.01. IR (KBr):  ν (cm-1) 3387 (br w), 2949 (m), 1560 (s), 1419 (s), 1295 (w), 1217 (w), 930 (w), 830 (m), 649 (w), 592 (w), 485 (w).

Ni 3 ( OH) 2 (1,4 - CDC) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ·4H 2 O, 2. The compound 2 was obtained by a procedure similar to that for compound 1 only changing the reaction temperature from 170 to 140 °C. Green platelike crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were separated by filtration. Yield:  30%. Elemental analysis (%) for 2 (C16H38O16Ni3):  calcd:  C:  29.00, H:  5.78; Found:  C:  29.41, H:  6.02. IR (KBr):  ν (cm-1) 3398 (br w), 2957 (m), 1560 (s), 1408 (s), 1296 (w), 1215 (w), 928 (w), 818 (m), 757 (w), 701 (w), 655 (w).

Ni(1,4-CDC)( H 2 O) 4 , 3. Compound 3 was obtained by a procedure similar to compound 1 only changing the reaction temperature from 170 to 120 °C. The product, light green platelets, was separated by filtration. Yield:  80%. Elemental analysis (%) for 3 (C8H18O8Ni):  calcd:  C:  31.93, H:  6.03; Found:  C:  31.67, H:  6.43. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) 3393 (br w), 2951 (m), 1562 (s), 1422 (s), 1294 (w), 1214 (w), 930 (w), 817 (m).

Experimental Section

 Synthesis. All chemicals were obtained from Aldrich and TCI and used without further purification. 

 Ni  6  (OH)  6  (1,4-CDC)  3  (H  2  O)  6 ⋅2H  2  O, 1. The mixture of 1,4-H2CDC (1.0 mmol, 0.1720 g), Ni(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O (1.0 mmol, 0.2490 g), cyclohexanol (5 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon autoclave and then heated at 170 °C for 3 days. The product, green hexagonal platelets, was separated by filtration. Yield: 35%. Elemental analysis (%) for 1 (C24H52O26Ni6): calcd: C: 26.00, H: 4.73; Found: C: 25.79, H: 5.01. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) 3387 (br w), 2949 (m), 1560 (s), 1419 (s), 1295 (w), 1217 (w), 930 (w), 830 (m), 649 (w), 592 (w), 485 (w). 

 Ni  3  ( OH)  2  (1,4 - CDC)  2  (H  2  O)  4 ⋅4H  2  O, 2. The compound 2 was obtained by a procedure similar to that for compound 1 only changing the reaction temperature from 170 to 140 °C. Green platelike crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were separated by filtration. Yield: 30%. Elemental analysis (%) for 2 (C16H38O16Ni3): calcd: C: 29.00, H: 5.78; Found: C: 29.41, H: 6.02. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) 3398 (br w), 2957 (m), 1560 (s), 1408 (s), 1296 (w), 1215 (w), 928 (w), 818 (m), 757 (w), 701 (w), 655 (w). 

 Ni(1,4-CDC)( H  2  O)  4  , 3. Compound 3 was obtained by a procedure similar to compound 1 only changing the reaction temperature from 170 to 120 °C. The product, light green platelets, was separated by filtration. Yield: 80%. Elemental analysis (%) for 3 (C8H18O8Ni): calcd: C: 31.93, H: 6.03; Found: C: 31.67, H: 6.43. IR (KBr): ν (cm-1) 3393 (br w), 2951 (m), 1562 (s), 1422 (s), 1294 (w), 1214 (w), 930 (w), 817 (m).

cln_elements.content:
Polynuclear core-based nickel 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate coordination polymers have been synthesized from an identical starting mixture at different temperatures. Ni6(OH)6(CDC)3(H2O)6·2H2O (1) forms a 2D layer based on novel hexanuclear nickel prismane cluster building units, while Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4·4H2O (2) forms a 3D open framework with a 1D channel of 17.1 × 3.5 Å2.

Magnetic Properties. The magnetic behaviors of compounds 1−3 are shown in the form of χM T versus T and χM versus T plots (Figure ). For compound 1, the value of χM T at room temperature (5.97 cm3 K mol-1) is lower than an expected value for six noninteracting NiII ions (S = 1) with g = 2.1 (6.62 cm3 K mol-1). On cooling of the sample, the χM T decreases slowly. This behavior suggests the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between NiII ions through μ3-OH and syn− syn carboxylate bridges. Here, a ferromagnetic contribution is also expected through a μ3-OH bridge with Ni−O(1)−Ni angles of 91.62 and 92.18° (see Table ). However, the spins of NiII ions are completely canceled in the Ni6 (even number) cluster core. The 1/χM vs T plot in the temperature range of 300−25 K obeys the Curie−Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ of −126 K, which is consistent with the magnetic behavior. The increase of χM value under 20 K is due to paramagnetic impurities. For 2, the χM T value at room temperature (3.55 cm3 mol-1 K) corresponds to three magnetically isolated NiII ions. χM T gradually increases from 3.84 to 4.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 40 K with lowering temperature. Under 40 K, χM T decreases more steeply down to 3.70 cm3 K mol-1 at 10 K and then again increases to 4.20 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The first increase of χM T can be attributed to a ferromagnetic interaction between Ni(2) centers through two μ3-OH bridges with Ni(2)−O(3)−Ni(2a) angle of 95.78° (see Table ). The decrease of χM T below 40 K results from an antiferromagnetic interaction between Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers through one μ3-OH bridge with a Ni(1)−O(3)−Ni(2) angle of 120.12°. The triangle Ni3 (odd number) core consists of one Ni(1) and two Ni(2) centers should have two remnant magnetic spins within the core due to the combination of the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic contributions. The abrupt increase of χM T under 10 K means a tendency of an ordering of remnant spins (ferrimagnetism) within the 1D chain. Ac susceptibility results show no long-range magnetic ordering until 2 K. A Curie−Weiss plot (300−40 K) gives a Weiss constant θ of 1.58 K. For 3, χM T gradually decreases from 1.14 to 1.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 30 K and then decreases more steeply down to 0.25 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which indicates contributions of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between spin centers and zero-field splitting of NiII ions. χM can be fit to the Curie−Weiss expression, χM = C/(T − θ), with C = 1.15 cm-3 mol K (g = 2.14), θ = −4.88 K.

Thermal Behavior of 2. The guest water molecules occupying the channels can be removed at an elevated temperature without collapsing the host framework as confirmed by TGA and X-ray diffraction studies (Figure ). The TG curve of 2 shows three main events between room temperature and 500 °C. The first (25−70 °C) is assigned to the removal of four equivalents of guest water molecules in the channels (obsd 9.1%, calcd 10.0%). The second event (120−150 °C) corresponds to the loss of four coordinated water molecules (obsd 11.0%, calcd 10.1%). The last weight loss of 52.9% (calcd 50.9%) between 290 and 440 °C corresponds to the elimination of the organic component.

Adsorption of 2. To confirm the permanent porosity of 2, samples of dehydrated 2 were subjected to gas adsorption measurements using CO2, Ar, and N2, whose kinetic diameters are known to be 3.3, 3.4, and 3.64 Å, respectively (Figure ). The adsorption measurements show that dehydrated 2 adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar and N2, which is associated with the kinetic diameters of the guest molecules versus the pore size. The sorption of CO2 revealed a type I behavior typical for microporous materials. The Langmuir surface area of 2 is calculated to be 146 m2 g-1. This type of framework could provide a subtle size of porous aperture which is useful for recognizing small size gas molecules.

Polynuclear core-based nickel 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate coordination polymers have been synthesized from an identical starting mixture at different temperatures. Ni6(OH)6(CDC)3(H2O)6⋅2H2O (1) forms a 2D layer based on novel hexanuclear nickel prismane cluster building units, while Ni3(OH)2(1,4-CDC)2(H2O)4⋅4H2O (2) forms a 3D open framework with a 1D channel of 17.1 × 3.5 Å2.

 Magnetic Properties. The magnetic behaviors of compounds 1-3 are shown in the form of χM T versus T and χM versus T plots (Figure ). For compound 1, the value of χM T at room temperature (5.97 cm3 K mol-1) is lower than an expected value for six noninteracting NiII ions (S = 1) with g = 2.1 (6.62 cm3 K mol-1). On cooling of the sample, the χM T decreases slowly. This behavior suggests the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions between NiII ions through μ3-OH and syn- syn carboxylate bridges. Here, a ferromagnetic contribution is also expected through a μ3-OH bridge with Ni-O(1)-Ni angles of 91.62 and 92.18° (see Table ). However, the spins of NiII ions are completely canceled in the Ni6 (even number) cluster core. The 1/χM vs T plot in the temperature range of 300-25 K obeys the Curie-Weiss law with a Weiss constant θ of -126 K, which is consistent with the magnetic behavior. The increase of χM value under 20 K is due to paramagnetic impurities. For 2, the χM T value at room temperature (3.55 cm3 mol-1 K) corresponds to three magnetically isolated NiII ions. χM T gradually increases from 3.84 to 4.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 40 K with lowering temperature. Under 40 K, χM T decreases more steeply down to 3.70 cm3 K mol-1 at 10 K and then again increases to 4.20 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The first increase of χM T can be attributed to a ferromagnetic interaction between Ni(2) centers through two μ3-OH bridges with Ni(2)-O(3)-Ni(2a) angle of 95.78° (see Table ). The decrease of χM T below 40 K results  from an antiferromagnetic interaction between Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers through one μ3-OH bridge with a Ni(1)-O(3)-Ni(2) angle of 120.12°. The triangle Ni3 (odd number) core consists of one Ni(1) and two Ni(2) centers should have two remnant magnetic spins within the core due to the combination of the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic contributions. The abrupt increase of χM T under 10 K means a tendency of an ordering of remnant spins (ferrimagnetism) within the 1D chain. Ac susceptibility results show no long-range magnetic ordering until 2 K. A Curie-Weiss plot (300-40 K) gives a Weiss constant θ of 1.58 K. For 3, χM T gradually decreases from 1.14 to 1.01 cm3 K mol-1 between 300 and 30 K and then decreases more steeply down to 0.25 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which indicates contributions of weak antiferromagnetic interactions between spin centers and zero-field splitting of NiII ions. χM can be fit to the Curie-Weiss expression, χM = C/(T - θ), with C = 1.15 cm-3 mol K (g = 2.14), θ = -4.88 K.

The guest water molecules occupying the channels can be removed at an elevated temperature without collapsing the host framework as confirmed by TGA and X-ray diffraction studies (Figure ). The TG curve of 2 shows three main events between room temperature and 500 °C. The first (25-70 °C) is assigned to the removal of four equivalents of guest water molecules in the channels (obsd 9.1%, calcd 10.0%). The second event (120-150 °C) corresponds to the loss of four coordinated water molecules (obsd 11.0%, calcd 10.1%). The last weight loss of 52.9% (calcd 50.9%) between 290 and 440 °C corresponds to the elimination of the organic component.  

 Adsorption of 2. To confirm the permanent porosity of 2, samples of dehydrated 2 were subjected to gas adsorption measurements using CO2, Ar, and N2, whose kinetic diameters are known to be 3.3, 3.4, and 3.64 Å, respectively (Figure ). The adsorption measurements show that dehydrated 2 adsorbs CO2 into its pores and shows nonporous behavior toward Ar and N2, which is associated with the kinetic diameters of the guest molecules versus the pore size. The sorption of CO2 revealed a type I behavior typical for microporous materials. The Langmuir surface area of 2 is calculated to be 146 m2 g-1. This type of framework could provide a subtle size of porous aperture which is useful for recognizing small size gas molecules.

cln_elements.content:
Crystallographic Data for Compounds1−3

1 2 3 chemical formula C24H52O26Ni6 C16H38O18Ni3 C8H18O8Ni formula weight 1108.7 694.4 300.7 crystal system trigonal monoclinic triclinic space group R-3c C2/m P1̄ a (Å) 14.787(4) 20.0967(10) 4.9139(11) b (Å) 14.787(4) 9.9992(5) 6.2914(15) c (Å) 31.231(11) 6.3722(4) 9.589(2) α (°) 90 90 79.652(9) β (°) 90 97.086(3) 78.857(11) γ (°) 120 90 77.044(9) V (Å3) 5914(3) 1270.72(12) 280.57(11) Z 36 8 2 λ (Å) 0.71070 0.71070 0.71070 D calcd (g cm-3) 1.831 1.768 1.355 μ (Mo Kα) (cm-1) 2.898 2.281 1.710 T (K) 293 293 293 unique reflns 1165 1506 925 R int 0.0522 0.0446 0.0085 R a /wR b 0.0436/0.1037 0.0408/0.1154 0.0353/0.1044

a   R =∑||F 0| − |F c||/∑|F 0|. b   wR = |∑w(|F 0|2 − |F c|2)|/∑|w(F 0)2|1/2, w = 1/[σ2(F 0 2) + (0.0391P)2 + 79.7608P], where P = (max(F 0 2, 0) + 2F c 2)/3 for 1. w = 1/[σ2(F 0 2) + (0.0589P)2 + 7.1849P], where P = (max(F 0 2, 0) + 2Fc2)/3 for 2. w = 1/[σ2(F 0 2) + (0.0559P)2 + 0.3605P], where P = (max(F 0 2, 0) + 2Fc2)/3 for 3.
